question: In contrast to the liquid rocket in Fig. P3.34, the solid-propellant rocket in Fig. P3.35 is self-contained and has no entrance ducts. Using a control-volume analysis for the conditions shown in Fig. P3.35, compute the rate of mass loss of the propellant, assuming that the exit gas has a molecular weight of 28. <image 1>
description:
The image depicts a schematic of a solid-propellant rocket engine, labeled as "Fig. P3.35." The diagram shows the flow of propellant through the combustion chamber and out through the exit section. Key information provided includes:

- The propellant enters the combustion chamber.
- Combustion occurs at a temperature of 1500 K and a pressure of 9.50 kPa.
- The exit section has an area \( A_e \) of 18 cm².
- The exit pressure \( p_e \) is 90 kPa.
- The exit velocity \( V_e \) is 150 m/s.
- The exit temperature \( T_e \) is 750 K.
- The molecular weight of the exit gas is given as 28.

The diagram also indicates that there are no entrance ducts, implying that the propellant is self-contained within the rocket.
